|Title=Knowing the diagnostic criteria for functional bowel disorders
|Description= Abdominal pain >1 day/month in the last 3 months with 2 criteria (associated with defecation/associated with a change in stool frequency and/or consistency).
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=
|Order=2}}
Irritable bowel syndrome is defined by the Rome criteria. They correspond to the presence of recurrent abdominal pain, occurring at least one day a week over the last three months, with at least two of the following criteria:

- 1) abdominal pain associated with defecation,

- 2) abdominal pain associated with a change in the frequency of bowel movements,

- 3) or abdominal pain associated with a change in the appearance of the stools.

Symptoms must have been present for at least six months before a diagnosis can be made.

question.title: What is the minimum duration of symptoms required before a diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) can be made?
question.description: According to the Rome criteria, how long must symptoms of IBS have been present before a diagnosis can be made?

option_a.title: At least 3 months
option_a.description: Symptoms must have been present for at least 3 months before a diagnosis can be made.

option_b.title: At least 6 months
option_b.description: Symptoms must have been present for at least 6 months before a diagnosis can be made.

option_c.title: At least 1 year
option_c.description: Symptoms must have been present for at least 1 year before a diagnosis can be made.

option_d.title: Symptom-free for 6 months
option_d.description: Symptoms must be symptom-free for at least 6 months before a diagnosis can be made.
